question:
Which of the following duties is specified as the 10th Fundamental Duty in the Indian Constitution?

SSC CHSL Tier II 18/11/2024
option_1: To strive towards excellence in all spheres of individual and collective activity
option_2: To provide opportunities for education to his child or as the case maybe, ward between the age of six and fourteen years
option_3: To cherish and follow the noble ideals which inspired our national struggle for freedom
option_4: To develop the scientific temper, humanism and the spirit of inquiry and reform
solution:
• The 10th Fundamental Duty in the Indian Constitution is:

    (a) To strive towards excellence in all spheres of individual and collective activity so that the nation constantly rises to higher levels of endeavor and achievement.

  • It is listed as Clause (j) under Article 51A of the Constitution.

Additional Information:

  • Fundamental Duties were incorporated into the Constitution through the 42nd Constitutional Amendment Act, 1976, based on the recommendations of the Swaran Singh Committee.
  • Originally, there were 10 Fundamental Duties, and an 11th duty was added in 2002 via the 86th Constitutional Amendment:
    • To provide opportunities for education to his child or ward between the age of 6 and 14 years (Option b).

question:
Which of the following is NOT the feature of Fundamental Duties provided under the Constitution of India?

SSC CHSL Tier II 18/11/2024
option_1: Duties are inspired from erstwhile USSR
option_2: Duties are non- justiciable in nature
option_3: Duties are enforceable by the law
option_4: Duties are intended to secure the country
solution:
• The correct answer is (c) Duties are enforceable by the law, because Fundamental Duties are not directly enforceable by the courts.
  • Fundamental Duties are listed under Article 51A of the Constitution and were added by the 42nd Constitutional Amendment Act, 1976.
  • Although these duties are non-justiciable (i.e., not legally enforceable in a court of law), the Parliament can make laws to enforce them indirectly.

Explanation of Options:

  • (a) Duties are inspired from erstwhile USSR – ✔️ True. The concept was taken from the Soviet Constitution.
  • (b) Duties are non-justiciable in nature – ✔️ True. They are moral obligations and not enforceable by courts.
  • (c) Duties are enforceable by the law – ❌ False. This is NOT a feature of Fundamental Duties; hence, this is the correct answer to the question.
  • (d) Duties are intended to secure the country – ✔️ True. They promote national integrity, discipline, and civic responsibility.

question:
Right of a prisoner to speedy trial will be categorised in which of the following Fundamental Rights?

SSC MTS 23/10/2024 (1st Shift)
option_3: Right to Constitutional Remedies
solution:
• The Right of a prisoner to a speedy trial falls under (b) Right to Life.
  • It is part of the Fundamental Right guaranteed under Article 21 of the Indian Constitution:

    “No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.”

  • The Supreme Court of India has interpreted Article 21 to include the right to a fair and speedy trial, especially for undertrial prisoners.

Key Judgments:

  • In Hussainara Khatoon v. State of Bihar (1979), the Supreme Court held that speedy trial is a fundamental right implicit in Article 21.
  • It emphasized that delays in trials violate the personal liberty of the accused.

Additional Information:

  • Article 21 ensures protection from:
    • Arbitrary arrest or detention
    • Inhuman prison conditions
    • Delay in legal proceedings
  • The right aims to protect dignity and fairness in the criminal justice system.

question:
Which article has a similar provision to that of Article 32 and deals with writ jurisdiction?

SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (d) Article 226.
  • Article 226 of the Indian Constitution empowers High Courts to issue writs for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights and for any other purpose.
  • It is similar to Article 32, which allows the Supreme Court to issue writs, but Article 226 is wider in scope because it is not limited to Fundamental Rights alone.

Difference between Article 32 and 226:

  • Article 32 (Supreme Court): Can issue writs only for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights.
  • Article 226 (High Courts): Can issue writs for enforcement of Fundamental Rights and other legal rights.

Types of Writs:

  • Habeas Corpus – produce the body
  • Mandamus – we command
  • Prohibition – to forbid
  • Certiorari – to be certified
  • Quo Warranto – by what authority

Additional Information:

  • Article 32 is considered the “heart and soul” of the Constitution (as per Dr. B.R. Ambedkar).
  • High Courts have territorial jurisdiction, whereas the Supreme Court has nationwide jurisdiction.

question:
Which Article of the Indian Constitution prohibits providing of any religious instruction in the educational institutions maintained by the State?

SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) Article 28 of the Indian Constitution.
  • Article 28 deals with the freedom as to attendance at religious instruction or religious worship in certain educational institutions.
  • It prohibits the imparting of religious instruction in any educational institution wholly maintained out of State funds.

Key Provisions of Article 28:

  1. Clause (1): No religious instruction shall be provided in any educational institution wholly maintained by State funds.
  2. Clause (2): Religious instruction is allowed in institutions administered by the State but established under endowments or trusts which require such instruction.
  3. Clause (3): No person attending any educational institution shall be compelled to take part in religious instruction or worship without their or their guardian’s consent.

Additional Information:

  • Articles 25 to 28 in Part III of the Constitution deal with Right to Freedom of Religion.
  • This ensures secularism, one of the basic features of the Indian Constitution.

question:
Which of the following Articles of the Indian Constitution contains Fundamental Duties?

SSC CGL 10/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (d) Article 51A.
  • Article 51A of the Indian Constitution lists the Fundamental Duties of every Indian citizen.
  • These duties were not originally part of the Constitution but were added later through the 42nd Constitutional Amendment Act, 1976.

Key Points about Article 51A:

  • It is included in Part IV-A of the Constitution.
  • Initially, it laid down 10 Fundamental Duties.
  • An 11th duty was added by the 86th Constitutional Amendment Act, 2002:
    • To provide opportunities for education to his child or ward between the age of six and fourteen years.

List Includes Duties Such As:

  • Abide by the Constitution and respect its ideals.
  • Cherish noble ideals of the freedom struggle.
  • Promote harmony and the spirit of brotherhood.
  • Safeguard public property and abjure violence.
  • Develop scientific temper and humanism.

Additional Information:

  • Though not enforceable by law, Parliament can make laws to implement them.
  • These duties serve as moral obligations for responsible citizenship.

question:
A student, on his school assignment, is taking a session on how to make compost at home for using it at a park. Which fundamental duty is he performing?

SSC CGL 12/09/2024 (1st Shift)
option_1: To strive towards excellence in all spheres of individual and collective activity
option_2: To safeguard public property and to abjure violence
option_3: To develop the scientific temper, humanism and the spirit of inquiry
option_4: To protect and improve the natural environment
solution:
• The correct answer is (d) To protect and improve the natural environment.
  • The student's action of teaching how to make compost at home contributes to waste management, recycling, and environmental awareness.
  • This aligns with the Fundamental Duty under Article 51A(g), which states:

    “It shall be the duty of every citizen of India to protect and improve the natural environment including forests, lakes, rivers and wildlife, and to have compassion for living creatures.”

Additional Information:

  • Making compost reduces organic waste, improves soil quality, and reduces the need for chemical fertilizers—all of which are eco-friendly practices.
  • This action also spreads environmental awareness, especially among the younger generation, promoting sustainable living.

question:
Which Article in the fundamental duty applies, when a construction worker takes his 8-year son to the site rather than sending him to school?

SSC CGL 13/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) Article 51A (k).
  • Article 51A(k) of the Indian Constitution states:

    "It shall be the duty of every citizen of India who is a parent or guardian to provide opportunities for education to his child or, as the case may be, ward between the age of six and fourteen years."

  • In this case, the construction worker is violating this duty by taking his 8-year-old son to work instead of sending him to school.

Additional Information:

  • This provision was added by the 86th Constitutional Amendment Act, 2002.
  • It complements Article 21A, which provides the Right to Education as a Fundamental Right.
  • Non-compliance with this duty affects not only the child's future but also the nation's development.

question:
Which of the following duties has been NOT prescribed by the Indian Constitution as Fundamental Duties?

To defend the country

2. To pay income tax

3. To cast the vote in election

4. To safeguard the public property

SSC CGL 17/09/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (c) 2 and 3 both.
  • Out of the listed options, "To pay income tax" and "To cast the vote in election" are not prescribed as Fundamental Duties in the Indian Constitution.
  • These may be civic responsibilities, but they are not part of Article 51A, which enumerates the 11 Fundamental Duties.

Analysis of Each Option:

  1. To defend the country – ✔️Yes, it is covered under Article 51A(d):

    “To defend the country and render national service when called upon to do so.”

  2. To pay income tax – ❌No, it is a legal obligation, not a Fundamental Duty.
  3. To cast the vote in election – ❌No, it is a statutory right, not a constitutional duty.
  4. To safeguard the public property – ✔️Yes, it is under Article 51A(i).

Additional Information:

  • The Fundamental Duties were added by the 42nd Constitutional Amendment Act, 1976.
  • Paying taxes and voting are important civic duties, but they are not part of the Fundamental Duties listed in the Constitution.

question:
Which fundamental duty applies on you when you see a few school students, on their educational trip to Humayun’s tomb, writing their names on the walls?

SSC CGL 17/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
option_1: To safeguard public property
option_2: To defend the country and render national service
option_3: To uphold and protect the sovereignty, unity and integrity of India
option_4: To protect and improve the natural environment
solution:
• The correct answer is (a) To safeguard public property.
  • Writing names on heritage structures like Humayun’s Tomb is an act of vandalism, which directly violates this Fundamental Duty.
  • As per Article 51A(i) of the Indian Constitution, every citizen must:

    "Safeguard public property and to abjure violence."

  • Monuments like Humayun’s Tomb are part of our national heritage and maintained by public funds, hence considered public property.

Additional Information:

  • Damaging public monuments is punishable under:
    • Prevention of Damage to Public Property Act, 1984
    • Ancient Monuments and Archaeological Sites and Remains Act, 1958
  • Citizens are morally and constitutionally obligated to preserve public infrastructure, including historical sites.

question:
Which of the following Articles of the Indian Constitution CANNOT be suspended even during an emergency declared on the grounds of war or external aggression?

SSC CGL 19/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) Articles 20 and 21.
  • Article 20 provides protection in respect of conviction for offences, and Article 21 guarantees the Right to Life and Personal Liberty.
  • These two articles are non-suspendable, meaning they cannot be suspended even during a National Emergency declared under Article 352 (on grounds of war or external aggression).

Why Articles 20 & 21 are special:

  • This was upheld by the 44th Constitutional Amendment Act, 1978, which inserted a safeguard stating:

"Articles 20 and 21 shall not be suspended even during a National Emergency."

  • Hence, even during the gravest emergencies, a person:
    • Cannot be punished for an act that was not a crime at the time it was committed (Article 20).
    • Cannot be deprived of life or liberty except according to procedure established by law (Article 21).

Additional Information:

  • Other Fundamental Rights (except 20 & 21) can be curtailed or suspended under Article 359 during an Emergency.
  • However, Article 19 can only be suspended during a war or external aggression, not internal disturbance.

question:
Which fundamental duty applies to you when you see your college friends start fighting with the canteen person when he passes a few anti-religious statements?

SSC CGL 24/09/2024 (1st Shift)
option_1: To promote harmony and spirit of brotherhood
option_2: To value and preserve the rich heritage
option_3: To develop the scientific temper, humanism, and the spirit of inquiry
option_4: To protect and improve our natural environment
solution:
• The correct answer is (a) To promote harmony and spirit of brotherhood.
  • This situation involves a conflict arising from religious sentiments, where the appropriate response is to discourage violence and promote tolerance and unity.
  • Article 51A(e) of the Indian Constitution directs citizens:

    "To promote harmony and the spirit of common brotherhood amongst all the people of India transcending religious, linguistic and regional or sectional diversities."

Why this applies:

  • The fundamental duty urges citizens to maintain peace, understand differences, and act in a way that encourages social harmony, especially in sensitive situations involving religion.

Additional Information:

  • Taking violent action or supporting aggressive behavior in such cases is against the spirit of constitutional duties.
  • Instead, resolving such issues peacefully, possibly by informing authorities or discouraging aggressive behavior, aligns with this duty.

question:
Which of the following statements is INCORRECT regarding Fundamental Rights?

SSC CGL 24/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
option_1: Fundamental Rights can be enforced by Law.
option_2: Fundamental rights are derived from the Britain Constitution.
option_3: The Fundamental Rights are mentioned in the constitution from article 12 to 35.
option_4: Article 21 provides the right to life.
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) Fundamental rights are derived from the Britain Constitution, which is INCORRECT.
  • In reality, Fundamental Rights in the Indian Constitution are inspired by the U.S. Bill of Rights, not from the British Constitution.
  • The British Constitution is unwritten and based on conventions, whereas the concept of enumerated and enforceable rights comes from the United States Constitution.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • (a) Fundamental Rights can be enforced by Law – ✔️ Correct. Citizens can move the Supreme Court (Article 32) or High Court (Article 226) to enforce Fundamental Rights.
  • (c) Fundamental Rights are mentioned in the Constitution from Article 12 to 35 – ✔️ Correct. Part III of the Indian Constitution deals with Fundamental Rights.
  • (d) Article 21 provides the Right to Life – ✔️ Correct. Article 21 states: "No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law."

Additional Information:

  • Fundamental Rights are justiciable and legally enforceable.
  • They are aimed at ensuring individual liberty, equality, and protection from arbitrary state action.

question:
If a 12-year-old is found to be working in a factory manufacturing carpets, which of the following Articles of the Constitution of India will be violated?

SSC CGL 25/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (a) Article 24.
  • Article 24 of the Indian Constitution prohibits the employment of children below the age of 14 years in any factory or mine or in any other hazardous employment.
  • So, if a 12-year-old is found working in a carpet manufacturing factory (considered hazardous), it is a clear violation of Article 24.

Text of Article 24:

“No child below the age of fourteen years shall be employed to work in any factory or mine or engaged in any other hazardous employment.”

Explanation of Other Options:

  • Article 23 – Prohibits human trafficking and forced labour.
  • Article 25 – Deals with freedom of religion.
  • Article 26 – Relates to freedom to manage religious affairs.

Additional Information:

  • The Child Labour (Prohibition and Regulation) Act, 1986 enforces Article 24.
  • Carpet manufacturing involves repetitive manual labor and exposure to chemicals, making it hazardous for children.
  • Violation of this provision is punishable under labour and penal laws.

question:
In which part of the Constitution will you find the six broad categories of Fundamental Rights?

SSC CHSL 01/07/2024 (1st shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (d) Part III.
  • Part III of the Indian Constitution (Articles 12 to 35) deals with Fundamental Rights.
  • These rights are guaranteed to all citizens and are justiciable, meaning they can be enforced through the courts.

Six Broad Categories of Fundamental Rights in Part III:

  1. Right to Equality (Articles 14–18)
  2. Right to Freedom (Articles 19–22)
  3. Right against Exploitation (Articles 23–24)
  4. Right to Freedom of Religion (Articles 25–28)
  5. Cultural and Educational Rights (Articles 29–30)
  6. Right to Constitutional Remedies (Article 32)

Additional Information:

  • Dr. B.R. Ambedkar called Article 32, the right to constitutional remedies, the "heart and soul" of the Constitution.
  • Fundamental Rights are inspired by the U.S. Bill of Rights, and aim to ensure individual liberty, equality, and dignity.

question:
Writ of Mandamus is a Fundamental Right classifiable under:

SSC CHSL 01/07/2024 (3rd shift)
option_1: cultural and educational rights
option_2: the right to freedom of religion
option_4: the right to equality
solution:
• The correct answer is (c) constitutional remedies.
  • The Writ of Mandamus is one of the five writs mentioned under Article 32 and Article 226 of the Indian Constitution.
  • These writs are part of the Right to Constitutional Remedies, which is classified under Part III of the Constitution.

About Writ of Mandamus:

  • It is a judicial order issued by a court to a public authority or official, directing them to perform a public duty which they have failed or refused to do.
  • Mandamus cannot be issued:
    • Against a private individual/body
    • Against the President or Governors
    • Against a judge acting in a judicial capacity

Other Writs under Article 32:

  1. Habeas Corpus
  2. Mandamus
  3. Prohibition
  4. Certiorari
  5. Quo-Warranto

Additional Information:

  • Article 32 (Right to move the Supreme Court for enforcement of Fundamental Rights) was called the “heart and soul” of the Constitution by Dr. B.R. Ambedkar.
  • This right is essential for protecting all other Fundamental Rights.

question:
Which of the following Articles prohibits traffic in human beings and forced labour?

SSC CHSL 01/07/2024 (4th shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) Article 23.
  • Article 23 of the Indian Constitution prohibits trafficking in human beings, begar (forced labour without payment), and other similar forms of forced labour.
  • It applies to both the State and private individuals, and any contravention of this article is punishable by law.

Text of Article 23(1):

"Traffic in human beings and begar and other similar forms of forced labour are prohibited and any contravention of this provision shall be an offence punishable in accordance with law."

Explanation of Other Options:

  • Article 22 – Protection of rights of arrested persons.
  • Article 25 – Freedom of religion and conscience.
  • Article 28 – Freedom from religious instruction in state-funded institutions.

Additional Information:

  • This article is part of the Right against Exploitation (Articles 23–24) under Part III (Fundamental Rights).
  • Article 24 complements this by prohibiting child labour in hazardous occupations.

question:
Which Clause of Article 20 incorporates the doctrine of double jeopardy?

SSC CHSL 02/07/2024 (1st shift)

Article 20 of the Constitution of India is related to _____.

SSC CHSL 02/07/2024 (2nd shift)
option_1: equality of opportunities in matters of public employment
option_2: protection in respect of conviction for offenses
option_3: freedom to manage religious affairs
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) protection in respect of conviction for offenses.
  • Article 20 of the Indian Constitution provides important safeguards to persons accused of criminal offenses.
  • It is available to both citizens and foreigners, and remains applicable even during a national emergency.

Article 20 contains three key protections:

  1. Article 20(1): No person shall be convicted for an act that was not an offence at the time it was committed (protection from retrospective criminal laws).
  2. Article 20(2): No person shall be prosecuted and punished for the same offence more than once (double jeopardy).
  3. Article 20(3): No person accused of any offence shall be compelled to be a witness against himself (protection against self-incrimination).

Explanation of Other Options:

  • (a) Article 16 – Equality of opportunity in public employment.
  • (c) Article 26 – Freedom to manage religious affairs.
  • (d) Article 18 – Abolition of titles.

Additional Information:

  • These protections under Article 20 uphold the principles of natural justice and rule of law.
  • They ensure that no arbitrary punishment is imposed and legal fairness is maintained during trials.

question:
Which of the following Articles of the Constitution states that ‘It shall be the duty of every citizen of India to promote harmony and the spirit of common brotherhood amongst all the people of India transcending religious, linguistic and regional or sectional diversities; to renounce practices derogatory to the dignity of women.’?

SSC CHSL 02/07/2024 (3rd shift)

___________ has called the Right to Constitutional Remedy as the ‘Soul of the Constitution’.

SSC CHSL 02/07/2024 (4th shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (d) Dr. B.R. Ambedkar.
  • Dr. B.R. Ambedkar, the chief architect of the Indian Constitution, referred to the Right to Constitutional Remedies (Article 32) as the “heart and soul of the Constitution”.
  • This article empowers citizens to approach the Supreme Court directly if any of their Fundamental Rights are violated.

About Article 32:

  • Provides the right to move the Supreme Court for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.
  • Includes provision for the issuance of writs: Habeas Corpus, Mandamus, Certiorari, Prohibition, and Quo Warranto.
  • Enforceable by both Supreme Court (Article 32) and High Courts (Article 226).

Explanation of Other Options:

  • Jawaharlal Nehru – First Prime Minister; associated with India’s political vision, not specifically with this statement.
  • Lala Lajpat Rai – Indian freedom fighter but did not coin this phrase.
  • Bal Gangadhar Tilak – Known for his slogan “Swaraj is my birthright”, not for this legal doctrine.

Additional Information:

  • Article 32 is often regarded as the “guardian of Fundamental Rights”.
  • It plays a crucial role in maintaining the rule of law and democratic framework in India.

question:
Certiorari comes under the:

SSC CHSL 03/07/2024 (1st shift)
option_1: right to religious freedom
option_2: right to constitutional remedies
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) right to constitutional remedies.
  • Certiorari is one of the five writs that can be issued under Article 32 (by the Supreme Court) or Article 226 (by the High Courts) to enforce Fundamental Rights.
  • It falls under the Right to Constitutional Remedies, which is guaranteed in Article 32 of the Indian Constitution.

About the Writ of Certiorari:

  • Certiorari is issued by a higher court to a lower court or tribunal.
  • Purpose: To quash an order or decision passed by a lower court or tribunal if it acted without jurisdiction or in violation of principles of natural justice.
  • It is corrective in nature.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • (a) Right to religious freedom – Articles 25–28.
  • (c) Right against exploitation – Articles 23–24.
  • (d) Right to equality – Articles 14–18.

Additional Information:

  • The other four writs under Article 32 and 226 are:
    1. Habeas Corpus – “produce the body”
    2. Mandamus – “we command”
    3. Prohibition – stop a lower court from exceeding its jurisdiction
    4. Quo Warranto – “by what authority”

question:
_______ Fundamental Duties were added in Part-IV of the Constitution under Article 51-A in the year 1976 through the 42nd Constitutional Amendment.

SSC CHSL 03/07/2024 (1st shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (c) Ten.
  • In 1976, the 42nd Constitutional Amendment Act added 10 Fundamental Duties to the Indian Constitution under Article 51A, which is part of Part IVA.
  • These duties were inspired by the Constitution of the former USSR and aim to encourage civic responsibility among citizens.

List of the Original 10 Fundamental Duties (1976):

  1. Abide by the Constitution and respect national symbols.
  2. Cherish the ideals of the freedom struggle.
  3. Uphold the sovereignty, unity, and integrity of India.
  4. Defend the country and render national service.
  5. Promote harmony and brotherhood.
  6. Value and preserve the rich heritage of culture.
  7. Protect and improve the natural environment.
  8. Develop scientific temper, humanism, and the spirit of inquiry.
  9. Safeguard public property and abjure violence.
  10. Strive for excellence in all spheres.

Additional Information:

  • In 2002, the 86th Constitutional Amendment added an 11th Fundamental Duty:

    "To provide opportunities for education to children between 6 and 14 years."

question:
Which of the following statement(s) is/are INCORRECT vis-à-vis Fundamental Duties?

The 44th amendment Act introduced Fundamental duties in the Constitution.

2) Fundamental Duties were expanded by the 86th amendment act.

3) Article 51A entails respect for its ideals and institutions, national flag and the national anthem.

4) Fundamental Duty obliges parents to provide opportunities for education to their child between 6-14 years of age.

SSC CHSL 04/07/2024 (1st shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (a) 1
  • Statement 1: ❌Incorrect – Fundamental Duties were introduced by the 42nd Constitutional Amendment Act, 1976, not the 44th Amendment.
  • Statement 2: ✅Correct – The 86th Constitutional Amendment Act, 2002 added one more Fundamental Duty under Article 51A(k).
  • Statement 3: ✅Correct – Article 51A(a) mentions respect for the Constitution, its ideals and institutions, the National Flag, and the National Anthem.
  • Statement 4: ✅Correct – This Fundamental Duty obliges parents to provide opportunities for education to their child between 6–14 years of age.

Additional Information:

  • Total Fundamental Duties at present: 11
  • These duties are non-justiciable but serve as moral obligations for every citizen.

question:
How many fundamental duties were recommended to be inserted in the Indian Constitution by the Swarna Singh Committee?

SSC CHSL 04/07/2024 (2nd shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (d) 8
  • The Swaran Singh Committee, constituted in 1976 by the Indian government, was assigned the task of recommending changes to the Constitution.
  • It recommended the inclusion of 8 Fundamental Duties for Indian citizens.
  • However, when the 42nd Constitutional Amendment Act was passed in 1976, the Parliament added 10 Fundamental Duties (not just 8) under Article 51A.

Key Facts:

  • The committee was headed by Swaran Singh, the then External Affairs Minister.
  • The idea was inspired by socialist constitutions, especially that of the USSR.
  • Later, the 86th Amendment Act, 2002 added an 11th Fundamental Duty related to children's education.

Additional Information:

  • Fundamental Duties are non-justiciable but aim to promote a sense of civic responsibility and national unity.

question:
A ________ is issued to prevent an inferior court or tribunal from exceeding its jurisdiction, which is not legally vested, or acting without jurisdiction or acting against the principles of natural justice.

SSC CHSL 05/07/2024 (4th shift)
option_2: writ of habeas corpus
solution:
• The correct answer is (c) writ of prohibition
  • The writ of prohibition is issued by a higher court (like High Court or Supreme Court) to a lower court or tribunal to stop it from continuing proceedings that are outside its jurisdiction or violate principles of natural justice.
  • It is preventive in nature and is used before the judgment is delivered.

Key Features:

  • Directed at judicial or quasi-judicial bodies.
  • Ensures that courts/tribunals don’t act beyond their legal authority.
  • Cannot be issued against administrative or legislative bodies.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • (a) Quo-warranto – Challenges the authority of a person holding a public office.
  • (b) Habeas Corpus – Seeks to release a person from unlawful detention.
  • (d) Mandamus – Directs a public authority to perform a duty it has failed to do.

Additional Information:

  • All these writs are enforceable under Article 32 (Supreme Court) and Article 226 (High Courts) to protect Fundamental Rights.

question:
A housemaid gets her 12-year-old daughter to help in her work as a house cleaner at a residential colony instead of sending her to school. Which fundamental duty is violated by the housemaid?

SSC CHSL 08/07/2024 (3rd shift)
option_1: To provide opportunities for education to his/her child
option_2: To promote harmony and the spirit of common brotherhood
option_3: To defend the country and render national service
option_4: To safeguard public property and to abjure violence
solution:
• The correct answer is (a) To provide opportunities for education to his/her child
  • This Fundamental Duty is mentioned under Article 51A(k) of the Constitution of India.
  • It states that a parent or guardian must provide opportunities for education to their child between the ages of 6 to 14 years.
  • By engaging her 12-year-old daughter in labor instead of sending her to school, the housemaid violates this duty.

Key Points:

  • This duty was added through the 86th Constitutional Amendment Act, 2002.
  • It reinforces the Right to Education under Article 21A, making elementary education a legal right for all children aged 6–14.

Additional Information:

  • There are a total of 11 Fundamental Duties listed in Article 51A.
  • While these duties are not enforceable by courts, they act as moral obligations for responsible citizenship.

question:
Citizens are NOT discriminated against on the basis of religion, caste or sex because of:

SSC CHSL 08/07/2024 (3rd shift)
option_3: Right to Freedom of Religion
solution:
• The correct answer is (d) Right to Equality
  • The Right to Equality is enshrined in Articles 14 to 18 of the Indian Constitution.
  • Article 15 specifically prohibits the State from discriminating against any citizen on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth.
  • This right ensures equal treatment before the law and equal protection of the laws to all individuals.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • (a) Right to Freedom – Articles 19 to 22; guarantees freedom of speech, expression, movement, etc.
  • (b) Right against Exploitation – Articles 23 and 24; prevents human trafficking, forced labor, and child labor.
  • (c) Right to Freedom of Religion – Articles 25 to 28; guarantees religious freedom but does not address caste/sex-based discrimination directly.

Additional Information:

  • Article 14: Equality before law and equal protection of laws.
  • Article 15(2): No citizen shall be denied access to shops, public restaurants, hotels, and places of public entertainment on the grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth.

question:
How many Fundamental Rights were initially provided in the Constitution of India?

SSC CHSL 08/07/2024 (4th shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (a) Seven
  • When the Constitution of India came into force on 26 January 1950, it originally provided Seven Fundamental Rights.
  • These rights were enshrined in Part III (Articles 12 to 35) of the Constitution and were considered essential for the development and dignity of individuals.

The Original Seven Fundamental Rights were:

  1. Right to Equality (Articles 14–18)
  2. Right to Freedom (Articles 19–22)
  3. Right against Exploitation (Articles 23–24)
  4. Right to Freedom of Religion (Articles 25–28)
  5. Cultural and Educational Rights (Articles 29–30)
  6. Right to Property (Article 31)
  7. Right to Constitutional Remedies (Article 32)

What changed?

  • The 44th Constitutional Amendment Act, 1978 deleted the Right to Property as a Fundamental Right.
  • It was moved to Article 300A under the Directive Principles (Part XII), making it a legal right, not a fundamental one.

Presently, there are 6 Fundamental Rights.

Additional Information:

  • Fundamental Rights are enforceable by courts and protect citizens against arbitrary actions of the state.
  • Article 32 is called the “Heart and Soul of the Constitution” as per Dr. B.R. Ambedkar.

question:
______ of the Constitution of India has provisions for legal enforcement of the fundamental rights.

SSC CHSL 08/07/2024 (4th shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (a) Article 32
  • Article 32 of the Constitution of India provides the right to constitutional remedies, which allows individuals to approach the Supreme Court directly for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights.
  • It empowers the Supreme Court to issue writs such as Habeas Corpus, Mandamus, Prohibition, Certiorari, and Quo-Warranto.

Key Points:

  • Dr. B.R. Ambedkar called Article 32 the "heart and soul of the Constitution."
  • It guarantees that Fundamental Rights are not just theoretical, but can be legally enforced through the courts.
  • High Courts are also empowered to enforce Fundamental Rights under Article 226.

Additional Information:

  • Article 32 can only be used to enforce Fundamental Rights, not other constitutional or legal rights.
  • The writ jurisdiction under Article 32 is a Fundamental Right in itself.

question:
Which of the following Fundamental Rights has been deleted from the original list of fundamental rights provided in the Constitution of India?

SSC CHSL 09/07/2024 (3rd shift)
option_2: Cultural and educational rights
option_3: Right to constitutional remedies
option_4: Right to freedom of religion
solution:
• The correct answer is (a) Right to property
  • The Right to Property was originally a Fundamental Right under Article 31 of the Constitution.
  • However, it was removed from the list of Fundamental Rights by the 44th Constitutional Amendment Act, 1978.
  • It is now a legal right under Article 300A in Part XII of the Constitution.

Why was it removed?

  • To make land reform laws and social welfare policies more effective.
  • It was often misused to challenge such laws in court, hence it was downgraded from a Fundamental Right.

Additional Information:

  • Currently, there are 6 Fundamental Rights.
  • The Right to Property can still be enforced in a civil court, but it does not enjoy the constitutional protection that Fundamental Rights have.

question:
Which of the following Fundamental Rights is available for Indians as well as foreigners?

SSC CHSL 10/07/2024 (1st shift)
option_1: Right to protection of language, script and culture of minorities
option_2: Equality of opportunity in matters of public employment
option_3: Right of minorities to establish and administer educational institutions
option_4: Right to elementary education
solution:
• The correct answer is (d) Right to elementary education
  • The Right to elementary education is part of Article 21A of the Constitution, added by the 86th Constitutional Amendment Act, 2002.
  • It guarantees free and compulsory education to all children aged 6 to 14 years, regardless of nationality, making it applicable to both Indians and foreigners residing in India.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • (a) Right to protection of language, script and culture of minorities – Available only to Indian citizens, particularly minorities (Article 29).
  • (b) Equality of opportunity in matters of public employment – Reserved only for Indian citizens (Article 16).
  • (c) Right of minorities to establish and administer educational institutions – Available only to Indian citizens (Article 30).

Additional Information:

  • Some Fundamental Rights like Articles 14, 20, 21, 21A, and 22 are available to both citizens and foreigners.
  • Article 21 (Right to Life and Personal Liberty) is particularly significant for all persons.

question:
All historical monuments have signages with instructions that public should not write on the walls. To which fundamental duty does the given statement belong?

SSC CHSL 10/07/2024 (3rd shift)
option_1: To defend the country and render national service
option_2: To safeguard public property and to abjure violence
option_3: To develop the scientific temper
option_4: To promote harmony and spirit of common brotherhood
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) To safeguard public property and to abjure violence
  • This Fundamental Duty is mentioned under Article 51A(i) of the Constitution of India.
  • It obligates every citizen to safeguard public property such as monuments, parks, roads, railways, and not damage or deface them.
  • Writing on historical monument walls is a violation of this duty.

Why is this important?

  • Public property belongs to all citizens and preserving it is a collective responsibility.
  • Acts like defacing monuments degrade national heritage and reflect irresponsibility.

Additional Information:

  • Fundamental Duties were added by the 42nd Constitutional Amendment Act, 1976.
  • Though not legally enforceable, they promote responsible citizenship and civic sense.

question:
Which of the following is NOT mentioned in fundamental duties provided under the Indian Constitution?

SSC CHSL 10/07/2024 (4th shift)
option_1: To safeguard public property
option_2: To develop scientific temper
option_3: To join Defence forces
option_4: To respect the national flag
solution:
• The correct answer is (c) To join Defence forces
  • Joining the Defence Forces is not mentioned as a Fundamental Duty under Article 51A of the Indian Constitution.
  • The Fundamental Duties outline moral obligations of citizens, such as respecting the Constitution, national flag, and institutions, but do not mandate military service.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • (a) To safeguard public property – Mentioned in Article 51A(i)
  • (b) To develop scientific temper – Mentioned in Article 51A(h)
  • (d) To respect the national flag – Covered under Article 51A(a)

Additional Information:

  • The 11 Fundamental Duties were added by the 42nd and 86th Constitutional Amendments.
  • They serve as moral and civic responsibilities of every citizen but are not enforceable by law, unless made so by legislation.

question:
Which writ literally means 'what is your authority’?

SSC CHSL 11/07/2024 (3rd shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (a) Quo-Warranto
  • The Latin term "Quo-Warranto" literally means "By what authority" or "What is your authority?"
  • This writ is issued by a court to a person holding a public office asking them to show by what authority they occupy that office.
  • It is used to prevent the illegal occupation of a public post that is not lawfully held.

Purpose of Quo-Warranto:

  • Ensures only qualified individuals hold public offices.
  • Helps maintain transparency and legality in appointments.

Explanation of Other Writs:

  • Habeas Corpus – "You may have the body"; to release a person unlawfully detained.
  • Mandamus – "We command"; directs a public official to perform a duty.
  • Prohibition – Issued by a higher court to a lower court to stop proceeding beyond jurisdiction.

Additional Information:

  • The writ jurisdiction of the Supreme Court is under Article 32, and for High Courts, under Article 226 of the Constitution.
  • Writs are a tool for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

question:
The original constitution did NOT mention any fundamental duty because:

SSC CHSL 11/07/2024 (4th shift)
option_1: initially fundamental duties were not expected to be performed
option_2: initially fundamental duties were punishable as per the constitution
option_3: it was expected that the citizens of the country would perform their duties willingly
option_4: it was expected that the citizens of the country would perform their duties forcefully
solution:
• The correct answer is (c) it was expected that the citizens of the country would perform their duties willingly
  • The original Constitution of India (1950) did not include Fundamental Duties.
  • The framers of the Constitution believed that Indian citizens, as responsible members of society, would perform their civic and moral duties voluntarily.
  • Hence, there was no separate chapter on Fundamental Duties in the original text.

When were they added?

  • Fundamental Duties were added later in 1976 by the 42nd Constitutional Amendment Act based on the recommendations of the Swaran Singh Committee.
  • These duties were included under Article 51A in Part IV-A of the Constitution.

Additional Information:

  • There are now 11 Fundamental Duties.
  • Although not enforceable by law, they can be promoted and encouraged through legal provisions and education.

SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (1st shift)
option_1: To uphold and protect the sovereignty, unity and integrity of India

question:
Abolition of titles is mentioned in which Article of the Indian Constitution?

SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (3rd shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) Article 18
  • Article 18 of the Indian Constitution deals with the abolition of titles.
  • It prohibits the State from conferring titles (except military or academic distinctions).
  • It also bars Indian citizens from accepting titles from foreign states.

Key Provisions of Article 18:

  • No title (except academic or military) shall be conferred by the State.
  • No citizen shall accept any title from any foreign State.
  • No foreigner holding any office of profit or trust under the State shall accept any title from any foreign State without the President’s consent.

Additional Information:

  • The abolition of titles promotes equality and non-discrimination, a core principle of the Right to Equality (Articles 14–18).
  • Titles like "Raja", "Maharaja", "Nawab" were discontinued after independence to ensure a democratic and egalitarian society.

question:
Article 21 is related to which of the following fundamental rights?

SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (2nd shift)
option_1: Freedom to Manage Religious Affairs
option_2: Protection of Language, Culture of Minorities
option_3: Protection of Life and Personal Liberty
solution:
• The correct answer is (c) Protection of Life and Personal Liberty.
  • Article 21 of the Indian Constitution states:

    “No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.”

  • It guarantees that the State cannot arbitrarily take away a person’s life or personal freedom.
  • This Article has been interpreted by the Supreme Court in a broad and progressive manner.

Key Rights included under Article 21:

  • Right to live with human dignity
  • Right to privacy
  • Right to clean environment
  • Right to education (for children aged 6 to 14, under Article 21A)
  • Right to legal aid and speedy trial

Additional Information:

  • Article 21 applies to citizens as well as foreigners.
  • It is considered one of the most important fundamental rights and is enforceable by courts under Article 32.

question:
If a person who is arrested, is NOT produced before the Magistrate within 24 hours from the time of arrest, he will be entitled to be released on the writ of ________.

SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (2nd shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (a) Habeas Corpus.
  • Habeas Corpus is a Latin term meaning “You may have the body.”
  • It is a writ issued by a court to produce a person who has been detained or imprisoned, ensuring their right to liberty is protected.
  • If a person is not produced before a magistrate within 24 hours of arrest (as per Article 22 of the Constitution and Section 57 of CrPC), it amounts to illegal detention.
  • In such a case, the court may issue a writ of Habeas Corpus to order their release.

Purpose of Habeas Corpus:

  • To prevent unlawful detention by the State.
  • To safeguard personal liberty and ensure judicial oversight over arrests.

Additional Information:

  • The writ can be filed by the detainee or anyone on their behalf.
  • It is enforceable under Article 32 (Supreme Court) and Article 226 (High Courts).

question:
The concept of limited government is a major advancement to protect the _______ of the citizens from the ruling governments.

SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (3rd shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (c) fundamental rights.
  • The concept of a limited government means that the powers of the government are restricted by law or a constitution.
  • This is done to ensure that the government does not infringe upon the fundamental rights and freedoms of its citizens.
  • A limited government operates within defined boundaries, often established by a written constitution.

Why it's important:

  • It helps prevent authoritarian rule or abuse of power.
  • Ensures that individual liberties and civil rights are preserved.
  • Protects democratic principles such as rule of law, equality, and justice.

Additional Information:

  • The Indian Constitution explicitly limits government power through Fundamental Rights (Part III).
  • Judicial review, separation of powers, and checks and balances are tools that support limited government.

question:
Which of the following articles guarantees the Right to Equality before the Law and the Right to Equal Protection of the Laws?

Matriculation Level 24/06/2024 (Shift- 4)
solution:
• The correct answer is (a) Article 14.
  • Article 14 of the Indian Constitution guarantees:
    • Equality before the law
    • Equal protection of the laws
  • This means the State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or equal protection of the laws within the territory of India.

Key Concepts:

  • Equality before law: No one is above the law; everyone is subject to the same laws in equal measure.
  • Equal protection of laws: Equal treatment under similar circumstances, allowing reasonable classification but prohibiting arbitrary discrimination.

Additional Information:

  • Article 14 is the foundation of the Right to Equality (Articles 14–18).
  • It applies to both citizens and foreigners.

question:
The 11th Fundamental Duty was added by which Amendment?

Higher Secondary 25/06/2024 (Shift- 2)
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) 86th Amendment 2002.
  • The 11th Fundamental Duty was added by the 86th Constitutional Amendment Act, 2002.
  • It introduced Article 51A(k) under Part IV-A of the Constitution.

What does the 11th Fundamental Duty state?

  • It makes it the duty of every parent or guardian to provide opportunities for education to their child (or ward) between the age of 6 and 14 years.

Additional Information:

  • The 42nd Amendment Act (1976) originally added 10 Fundamental Duties.
  • The 86th Amendment also added Article 21A, which made the Right to Education a Fundamental Right for children aged 6–14.

question: Which Article of the Indian Constitution mentions that every religious denomination or section shall have the right to own and acquire movable and immovable property?
solution:
• The correct answer is (a) Article 26(c).
  • Article 26 of the Indian Constitution grants every religious denomination certain rights concerning their religious affairs.
  • Specifically, Article 26(c) provides that every religious denomination shall have the right:

“to own and acquire movable and immovable property.”

Breakdown of Article 26:

  • (a): To establish and maintain institutions for religious and charitable purposes.
  • (b): To manage its own affairs in matters of religion.
  • (c): To own and acquire movable and immovable property.
  • (d): To administer such property in accordance with law.

Additional Information:

  • Article 26 is part of the Right to Freedom of Religion (Articles 25 to 28).
  • These rights are available to all religious denominations, subject to public order, morality, and health.

question:
Which Article of the Indian Constitution mentions that ‘No person shall be prosecuted and punished for the same offence more than once’?

Graduate Level 26/06/2024 (Shift- 4)
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) Article 20(2).
  • Article 20(2) of the Indian Constitution lays down the principle of "double jeopardy".
  • It states:

"No person shall be prosecuted and punished for the same offence more than once."

  • This provision protects an individual from being tried or punished twice for the same criminal act under the same law.

Key Concept – Double Jeopardy:

  • It ensures legal protection against repeated prosecution for the same offence.
  • However, a person can be prosecuted again if the offence and law are different.

Additional Information:

  • Article 20 provides protection in respect of conviction for offences and contains:
    • Clause (1): No ex-post facto laws
    • Clause (2): No double punishment for the same offence
    • Clause (3): No self-incrimination

question:
Which Committee had suggesteda penalty or punishment for the nonperformance of Fundamental Duties?

SSC CGL Tier II 26/10/2023
solution:
• The correct answer is (d) Swaran Singh Committee.
  • The Swaran Singh Committee was formed in 1976 during the Emergency under Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.
  • It was tasked with recommending the inclusion of Fundamental Duties in the Indian Constitution.
  • The committee suggested that citizens should be penalized for non-performance of Fundamental Duties, although this provision was not accepted in the final amendment.

Additional Information:

  • Based on this committee's recommendations, the 42nd Constitutional Amendment Act, 1976 added 10 Fundamental Duties to Part IV-A (Article 51A) of the Constitution.
  • However, no legal penalties were included in the Constitution; Fundamental Duties remain non-justiciable (not enforceable by courts).

question:
Which Article of the Constitution clarifies that policies like 'reservation' is not a violation of the right to equality?

SSC CPO 04/10/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• The correct answer is (a) Article 16(4).
  • Article 16 deals with equality of opportunity in public employment.
  • Clause (4) specifically states:

“Nothing in this article shall prevent the State from making any provision for the reservation of appointments or posts in favor of any backward class of citizens which, in the opinion of the State, is not adequately represented in the services under the State.”

Key Point:

  • Article 16(4) acts as an exception to the general rule of equality in public employment and permits reservation for socially and educationally backward classes, thus not violating the right to equality.

Additional Information:

  • Similarly, Article 15(4) allows for special provisions for advancement of backward classes in education.
  • These are constitutional mechanisms to ensure substantive equality and social justice.

question:
What is the purpose of the Cultural and Educational Rights?

SSC MTS 13/09/2023 (1st Shift)
option_1: To promote a particular religion
option_2: To protect the language, culture, and religion of the minority communities
option_3: To protect the majority community
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) To protect the language, culture, and religion of the minority communities.
  • The Cultural and Educational Rights are provided under Articles 29 and 30 of the Indian Constitution.
  • These rights are specifically aimed at safeguarding the interests of minorities.

Key Provisions:

  • Article 29: Protects the interests of minorities by allowing them to conserve their distinct language, script, or culture.
  • Article 30: Gives minorities the right to establish and administer educational institutions of their choice.

Additional Information:

  • These rights are applicable to both religious and linguistic minorities.
  • The goal is to ensure cultural diversity and inclusive education in a democratic society.

question:
Which of the following is enforceable by the Indian Constitution?

SSC CHSL 02/08/2023 (3rd shift)
option_3: Directive Principles of State Policy
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) Fundamental rights.
  • Fundamental Rights (Articles 12–35) are legally enforceable by the Constitution of India.
  • A citizen can approach the courts (especially under Article 32 and Article 226) if these rights are violated.

Why not others?

  • Preamble: Not enforceable by courts; it acts as an introduction and guiding principle.
  • Directive Principles of State Policy (DPSPs): Found in Part IV (Articles 36–51), they are non-justiciable, meaning not legally enforceable in a court.
  • Fundamental Duties: Mentioned in Article 51A, they are moral obligations, not enforceable by law (except when made so by legislation).

Additional Information:

  • The Supreme Court has termed Fundamental Rights as the soul of the Constitution.
  • Article 32 is called the "heart and soul" by Dr. B.R. Ambedkar.

question:
Which of the following statements is FALSE about the right to freedom of religion mentioned in the Indian Constitution?

SSC CHSL 04/08/2023 (1st shift)
option_1: It provides freedom to manage religious affairs.
option_2: It provides freedom of worship.
option_3: It is mentioned in Articles 25 to 28.
option_4: It mentions that the state has its own religion.
solution:
• The correct answer is (d) It mentions that the state has its own religion, which is FALSE.
  • The Indian Constitution guarantees freedom of religion to all individuals but does not endorse any religion as the official religion of the state.
  • India is a secular state, meaning the state has no official religion and treats all religions equally.

Correct Points About Freedom of Religion:

  • (a) Article 26 ensures freedom to manage religious affairs.
  • (b) Article 25 provides freedom of conscience and the right to freely profess, practice and propagate religion.
  • (c) The right to freedom of religion is enshrined in Articles 25 to 28 of the Constitution.

Additional Information:

  • Article 27: No person shall be compelled to pay taxes for promotion of any particular religion.
  • Article 28: No religious instruction in state-funded educational institutions.

question:
Which statement is FALSE regarding fundamental rights mentioned in the Indian Constitution?

SSC CHSL 10/08/2023 (4th shift)
option_1: Only Article 20 and 21 can be suspended during emergency
option_3: Some fundamental rights are negative in nature
option_4: Can be suspended during emergency
solution:
• The correct answer is (a) Only Article 20 and 21 can be suspended during emergency, which is FALSE.
  • Articles 20 and 21 cannot be suspended even during an emergency (as per Article 359 of the Constitution).
  • Therefore, the statement that only Article 20 and 21 can be suspended is factually incorrect — the truth is the opposite: they cannot be suspended.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • (b) They are justiciable – ✅ Correct. Fundamental Rights can be enforced by courts.
  • (c) Some fundamental rights are negative in nature – ✅ Correct. E.g., Article 18 (Abolition of Titles), Article 17 (Abolition of Untouchability) prohibit certain actions.
  • (d) Can be suspended during emergency – ✅ Partially true. Most fundamental rights can be suspended during a national emergency except Articles 20 and 21.

Additional Information:

  • Article 359 empowers the President to suspend the right to move courts for enforcement of Fundamental Rights during an emergency, except Articles 20 and 21.
  • Article 20: Protection in respect of conviction for offenses
  • Article 21: Protection of life and personal liberty

question:
The celebration of Christmas, Eid and Holi in school is an example of making children learn fundamental duties as well. Which of the following fundamental duties advocates about this type of ideals?

SSC CHSL 14/08/2023 (1st shift)
option_1: To defend the country and render national service
option_2: To develop the scientific temper
option_3: To safeguard public property and to abjure violence
option_4: To promote harmony and spirit of common brotherhood
solution:
• The correct answer is (d) To promote harmony and spirit of common brotherhood.
  • Celebrating festivals like Christmas, Eid, and Holi in schools fosters mutual respect, tolerance, and a sense of unity in diversity among children.
  • This aligns with Article 51A(e) of the Indian Constitution, which states that it is the duty of every citizen:

"to promote harmony and the spirit of common brotherhood amongst all the people of India transcending religious, linguistic and regional or sectional diversities; to renounce practices derogatory to the dignity of women."

Additional Information:

  • Fundamental Duties were added to the Constitution by the 42nd Amendment Act, 1976.
  • There are 11 Fundamental Duties as of now.
  • These duties are non-justiciable but act as moral obligations for every citizen.

question:
What is the aim of fundamental rights mentioned in the Indian Constitution?

SSC CHSL 14/08/2023 (2nd shift)
option_1: To establish a welfare state
option_2: To have an absolute independence
solution:
• The correct answer is (d) To establish political democracy.
  • The Fundamental Rights enshrined in Part III of the Indian Constitution (Articles 12–35) primarily aim to protect individual liberty, ensure equality, and limit arbitrary power of the State — all of which are key features of political democracy.
  • These rights empower individuals to participate freely and fairly in the political process.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • (a) Welfare state – More closely associated with Directive Principles of State Policy.
  • (b) Absolute independence – No right is absolute; all are subject to reasonable restrictions.
  • (c) Economic justice – Also mainly addressed by the Directive Principles, not Fundamental Rights.

Additional Information:

  • Political democracy is strengthened through rights like:
    • Right to Equality (Article 14–18)
    • Right to Freedom (Article 19–22)
    • Right to Constitutional Remedies (Article 32)

question:
Fundamental duties are ______ and not enforceable by law but are taken into account by the courts while adjudicating any matter.

SSC CGL 27/07/2023 (2nd shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (c) statutory.
  • Fundamental Duties are described in Article 51A of the Indian Constitution, added by the 42nd Amendment Act, 1976.
  • While they are not directly enforceable by law (i.e., no punishment is prescribed for their violation unless specifically legislated), they are considered statutory duties because they are laid down by the Constitution, a statutory document.
  • Courts can refer to these duties during judgments to uphold the spirit of the Constitution.

Why not other options?

  • (a) Regulatory – This refers to rules or frameworks, not duties set in the Constitution.
  • (b) Non-statutory – Incorrect, because duties are mentioned in a statute (the Constitution).
  • (d) Common – Vague and not a legal classification.

Additional Information:

  • Although not justiciable, fundamental duties help guide citizen behavior and support national integration.
  • Some duties have been made enforceable by laws (e.g., Protection of Environment under Environment Protection Act, 1986).

question:
Which of the following Articles of the Indian Constitution mentions the fundamental duty "sovereignty, unity and integrity of India" is mentioned?

SSC MTS 16/06/2023 (Morning)
solution:
• The correct answer is (c) Article 51A(c).
  • Article 51A(c) of the Indian Constitution states:

"It shall be the duty of every citizen of India to uphold and protect the sovereignty, unity and integrity of India."

  • This is one of the 11 Fundamental Duties, introduced by the 42nd Constitutional Amendment Act, 1976.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • Article 51A(b): Respect for ideals and institutions, national flag and anthem.
  • Article 51A(d): Defense of the country and rendering national service.
  • Article 51A(e): Promoting harmony and brotherhood.

Additional Information:

  • Fundamental Duties are non-justiciable, but serve as moral obligations.
  • They aim to promote civic responsibility and national unity.
